reviewText: Sometimes you find yourself swept up in a film for the sheer likability of the thing and then realize later (maybe even years later) that you really shouldn't have.  `Forever Young' is that kind of movie.  As a pre-teen my friends loved this movie and I have to admit, I had fond memories of it.  Watching it the other night, now very much NOT a pre-teen, proved the above statement.  While `Forever Young' does have its moments of sweetness and romanticism, the bottom line is that this film is really, really stupid.  None of it makes much sense, the relationships are ridiculously colored, the basic plot, while supposed to be science fiction and not entirely plausible (we forgive those aspects of the plot) is never really fleshed out enough to make it feel like anything more than a gimmick and the character development by anyone outside of Daniel (Mel Gibson's character) is so slight and preposterous that everyone looks like an idiot.I mean, really...I rarely see that many stupid people in a film that is supposed to be serious.Many will balk at this.  `Forever Young' is one of those strangely beloved minor classics, a film that no respecting critic would praise and yet the average movie going turns to as an example of a good movie.  But I ask you; why do you like this movie?  Is it because it is romantic?  Is it because Mel Gibson pines for his lost love and it has a sweetly satisfying happy ending?  Sure, those are nice things, but when the film lacks anything substantial to tie those moments together then you have a halfhearted attempt at filmmaking.The idea of cryogenics is merely used as a plot point, with no actual depth given to the process or the idea itself, so if you are coming into this thinking that it is actually a science fiction romance you can drop that idea at the door since this is nothing more than a standard romance colored with a shade of science fiction used more as a way to give this a faux sense of originality.  Don't even get me started on the desperate characterization of the character of Claire (played by Jamie Lee Curtis).  Her actions are appalling and really make this film almost laughable.  The fact that a single mother would offer her couch to a man she does not know who randomly barged in her house to save her from an abusive ex-husband is just odd and a gross representation of a romantic subplot.  The idea that the army thought the chamber Daniel was kept in was a water heater is just dumb and the all too easy resolve at the end (I have the documents, forget about the test subject) was ridiculous.Such a lazy way to tie up loose ends.So, I can't praise this or even recommend it.  Mel Gibson's performance is very good though, I'll admit that.  His early career was quite good and it is sad that he has been reduced to a mere laughingstock of a man who is referred to for his off-screen antics more than his work in front of the camera.  That said, even his earnest performance cannot save this mess of a film.  I'll give it a D, but that is only because the cinematography in parts is stunning and Gibson tries really hard to sell this mediocrity.

reviewText: Can you imagine losing the one you love just before you are going to pop the forever question? Neither could Mel Gibson so he has himself put in cryofreeze  but in a wonderful but sad and of course unbelievable mishap, Gibson is left frozen for like 40 years (give or take a year).What ensues is a romantic fate none of us may  ever want to happen to our romance. But for those hopeless romantics, like me, who have loved the same person for decades this story has a poignancy that soul mates, and those of us who never ever want to be without our love of a lifetime can find joy in.  If you are one of those forever, one man women, or one woman man, get out your tissue box, snuggle up to your honey and play the movie you are in for a memory.
summary: Sci fi meets romance and the combination is brilliant

reviewText: When a test pilot (Mel Gibson) almost lost his girlfriend (Isabel Glasser) in a accident. When he decide to croygencially himself frozen in 1939 only to wake up in 1992-Alone. reviewText: This is another of these frozen-in-time movies. I know at least two of them that were made in 1991-1992 and they were both fun to watch: this movie and "Late For Dinner."The good things that this particular film has going for it are: 1 - Mel Gibson plays a very likable lead character in "Captain Daniel McCormick;" 2 - there is a nice 1940s atmosphere in the beginning with a beautiful Isabell Glasser, who exhibits one of the sweetest faces and smiles I've seen on film; 3 - there is a good mix of humor, drama and intrigue, as well as fantasy in the story; 4 - there is a nice, almost tear-inducing ending.The film got criticized for being too unrealistic but, hey, it's supposed to be a fantasy story where everything is not explained.  Overall, a nice, touching movie.
summary: A Time Travel Movie With Feeling

reviewText: This is the very best sort of science-fiction. The type where the central concept is used to establish the situation, then forgotten about as the action concentrates on human relationships and character.Mel Gibson plays a World War II test pilot who is accidentally frozen for over fifty years and rediscovered in 1992. His story is about the love he lost in the 1930s, his friendship with two boys and the mother of one of them, and finally how he regains the love he lost.The sets for the cryogenic chamber are some of the best I have seen, with gleaming copper and brass making a believable 1930s hi-technology. The film does let itself down with the ageing make-up in its latter stages, despite the fact that two men receive an on-screen credit for 'special' make-up. The main characters are likeable, even the kid played by Elijah Wood in one of his early screen roles. Jamie Lee Curtis puts in a good performance, although it's amazing how she has time to look so good when she is a nurse and a mother and trying to find the man of her dreams!All in all an enjoyable film with an unexpected but romantic ending.
Title: N/A

reviewText: Forever Young is the kind of movie my mother likes-sweet, good old fashioned story, cute kid, no one gets really injured, depression is rewarded with joy and a happy ending. In fact my mother likes this movie and so do most viewers. My mom professes not to like science fiction. But, who cares when you have Mel Gibson at his handsome peak (something which has now peaked), and blue-eyed Elijah Wood filling in the saccharin when blue-eyed Mel is taking a rest. The fact is, Forever Young works on all levels.Old plot-man is suspended in time and wakes up in the future-zowie! Needs to adjust. Needs to find answers. Finds shelter and danger. A mixture of Always and Blast from the Past, Forever Young makes the old formula work by throwing in some-more old formulas. Take a love affair that almost was, but can never be. Add a desolation that has no bounds. Give it a margin of escape, into a world of cryogenics. Diffuse the sci-fi out of the picture. No one cares about the how and why (except George Wendt, who froze a chicken and brought it back to life and David Marshall Grant and his FBI cronies). Have the hero wake up, scare some nosey kids, get naked, wear women's clothes, and show up at the doorstep of a not-so-perfect household, but a not-that-dysfunctional one as well.What makes Forever Young endearing (and enduring as a classic) is Daniel's search for an answer from a man who is dead for many years; and of course, his still undying love for Helen (Isabel Glasser) even with the presence of Claire Cooper (Jamie Lee Curtis) to add sexual tension. Like the Billy Holiday theme song- "The very thought of you," the absence of a true love can still provoke an unquenchable yearning; and Mel Gibson does a bang up job of convincing us that despite 50 years missing, he is still the same old fashioned, 1939 guy in love with a woman who is far removed.Not necessary to the plot, but central to Forever Young's success is the then eleven year old Elijah Wood, who for one of the very few times in his seventeen year acting career, needs to play a kid. Most of his character portrayals of young folk are children deeply wounded or in the grips of Adult drama. In Forever Young he has the challenge of finding a character arc that really is not in the script. He finds one (bully for him), and has his character, Nat Cooper, rise above its meagerness, adding humor, sweetness, excitement and, well-I hate to say it, but he makes us feel Forever Young. The film is about the old folk finding youth. But, define Youth. Ah! That definition is supplied by none other than Elijah Wood, despite the acting challenge and his own personal flagging against the part during the film's shooting.Of course, the twist ending is perfect-something akin to To Each His Own or Imitation of Life (not the remake-the Original with Claudette Colbert). Overall, a peaceful, warm film, Forever Young will remain Forever Popular. Maybe because it offends no one, makes for a good Saturday afternoon DVD watch, and is, frankly my dear, a damn good film. A+.
summary: Forever Young - Old Fashioned Sweet Movie - Break out the Fudge

reviewText: I have to admit this movie was really good. Excellent actors, solid and easy to follow plot, and proof that true love endures forever. The ending almost made me shed a tear..dont worry it's a happy ending. This is not wishy washy Notebook material although that is a good movie in it's own right.. It starts out as his girlfriend has an accident, Gibson feels all is lost so he volunteers for an experiment, then after he is thawed goes around trying to piece together what he's missed over the years. All the while Gibson is aging in surges then finally he hears word of his former girlfriend,  and the story ends with one of the best endings possible...the rest is history. a real achievemnt for Gibson and quite the refreshing change from his action oriented roles..

reviewerName: Jacques COULARDEAU "A soul doctor, so to say"
reviewText: A very touching film because of some extremely sentimental and poignant elements. The girl that holds your heart and to whom you cannot propose crosses a road and gets hit by a truck. Coma..., irreversible..., they say. Better get frozen for later than live through this death. Frozen by some doctor who dies and leaves you behind and you are abandoned in a hangar. A couple of naughty boys revive you and then the real nightmare starts. They all believe you are nuts of course, except the mother of one of the boys, a nurse by profession he saves from an ex-whatever who wants to rape her. Finding your identity after 53 years in ice, that's hard. But there is a slight problem with Dorian Gray's picture. You are the picture and your age shows fast. Will he find and marry his sweetheart and is she still alive? Will he escape the cops and the doctors? Who knows? What will the little boy who revived him do? Nothing to say here. Just keep in mind this film is a piece of romantic beauty and that's all. The visit of the air force base I remember I must have done it in the same period, around 1990, one or two years more or less. That was a funny experience and I would have loved meeting Mel Gibson in one of the jets. But well no luck boy. Mel Gibson is nothing but a celluloid baby who has no real existence and his life is a dream and in this case the dream could have turned into a nightmare. Mel Gibson is a very flexible actor and manages romantic situations or situations with kids just as well as he does mad situations with Max and his tribe, not to speak of the mythic religious rewriting of the passion or the whole cosmos. There is something like a certain Connors and Schwarzenegger in that Gibson, even if he is a difficult spouse to get a divorce from. Back to the future then.Dr Jacques COULARDEAU, University Paris 1 Pantheon Sorbonne, University Paris 8 Saint Denis, University Paris 12 Créteil, CEGID
summary: Better romantic and die than pathetically mute

reviewText: I always say that Jamie Lee Curtis can lift any turkey of a film right out of turkeydom into a charming film. She has never gotten the credit or the roles she deserved. This movie is just a bit of fluff of course but you can't help but get caught up in it. Of course at the heart of it, which it would have been nice if the Mel Gibson character had vocalized at some point, is the fact that if he hadn't been such a cowardly jerk wanting to escape into something, anything, leaving the girl he supposedly loves to lie in a coma alone then he would have had those 50 years, that he threw away, with her.  But, then we wouldn't have had a story would we. The kid does a great job and I'm afraid that I'm now at the age where kids in movies usually just annoy me. This one was on target in the role.  Amazing eyes. Great casting on the doctor beau of the mother. Nice touch to this movie. If you are not looking for a bang up, shoot em dead, screaming car chase type of movie, you'll love this one. But, it's Jamie Lee's movie all the way.
summary: A great deal of charm in this movie

reviewText: Quick wrap: Guy gets frozen, is defrosted some 40-ish years later. No spoiler there - that's only the beginning of the story. Mel Gibson shows once again that he can take any role and put the viewer inside that character's head. It's not so much a sci-fi film as a what-if fantasy, with sprinkles of morality, pathos, and passion added in. A little corny at times, but not enough to hinder the storyline. All in all, a good flick that I can watch over and over.Gibson and Jaime Lee Curtis were great together, and it must have been tempting for the director to amplify that relationship. I'm glad he didn't though. The ending would have been off the 'captain obvious' scale. Sure it's a feel-good kinda flick with a happy ending, but what's wrong with that? This is one of the better offerings in that genre.BTW - if you're into vintage aircraft, you'll be drooling over the live-action B-25 scenes. Only problem is there wasn't enough of them. For me, anyway.

reviewText: This is an outstanding movie. Mel Gibson as a test pilot is very believable. The year 1939 is a pivot year for the world and me in general. The role as a test pilot in the old Army Air Corps is well suited for Mel Gibson. It is a romantic story of how great pictures are made dealing with love and romance. The old school feels as I do that it is not necessary to have people who love deeply jump into the sack together. There are other ways to express love by a touch or maybe a look. We who have been around a while know about our first love and how just maybe we mumbled and stumbled trying to express our love to the most important other person in the world. Whether you are male or female; old or young this picture has something for you. The picture also has a magic that after it ends one is left with a good feeling! We also may wonder what if that had happen to me; what would I have done. Jamie Lee Curtis in a supporting role also shines. Mel Gibson as test pilot Daniel McCormick has a terrific job flying B-25's. He also has found the love of his life in a devoted soulmate Isabel Glasser. When they are both on the screen you can see that these two are meant for each other! There is a lesson in this romantic tale that maybe we should not postponed things until tomorrow to pop the question. I won't say more because then I would reveal the plot but I will say that love as life last forever! You might say, "Whoa...but see the movie and then you will see first hand what I am talking about!" I loved it! I have also seen it a couple of times and the magic of Forever Young, is that it is a great romantic story about courage, taking risks, seizing the moment and in this story getting the opportunity for one more chance at love!Too Many Secrets

reviewText: One has to give superstar Mel Gibson a lot of credit.  Over his prolific career, Gibson has taken many risks in the roles he's chosen, and this romantic fantasy is just one of them.  FOREVER YOUNG opens in 1939, where daredevil test pilot Gibson finds himself involved with a scientist who is perfecting a cryogenics chamber.  He's also madly in love with the lovely Helen (Isabel Glasser), and wants to marry her.  Alas and alack, before he can pop the question, Helen is struck down by a truck and goes into a coma.  As the months go by, Gibson clings to hopes she'll recover but as his scientist friend (George Wendt) states, doctors give her little hope.  When Mel feels he can't watch Helen die, he volunteers to be the first human volunteer for the cryogenics project, asking Wendt to freeze him for a year so he can avoid the inevitable.  Next thing you know, it's 1992, and we meet single mom Jamie Lee Curtis (quite good as always) and her 10 year old son (Elijah Wood, simply charming, showing us what his future would be years later).  While playing in an abandoned military warehouse, Wood and his buddy stumble upon the cyrogenics chamber and accidentally release Gibson.  How he got caught in this chamber for 53 years forms the core of the story and Gibson desperately searches for some knowledge of Wendt's whereabouts.The movie is unabashedly romantic but Gibson is so good and the story takes hold of you and you watch with amusement as Gibson discovers the technologies of a new world and his scenes with young Wood are marvelous.  A rather contrived ending spoils the overall effect but FOREVER YOUNG is nonetheless a very engaging film.

reviewText: A perfect 1939 love story.  Boy meets girl, girl falls in love with boy, and boy gets put into a deep freeze (cryogenics) only to be accidentally brought back to life over 50 years later.  After being defrosted in 1992, Air Force Captain Daniel McCormick (Mel Gibson) starts falling in love with another woman, Claire Cooper (Jamie Lee Curtis).  Daniel is still in love with Helen (Isabel Glasser) and sets out to find her.  Daniel eventually discovers that Helen is still alive and is reunited with her at the end of the movie.

reviewText: FOREVER YOUNG (1992) is a color film about a military test pilot who volunteers for a cryogenic experiment in 1939, and who is inadvertently woken up in 1992 by two boys who discover his cryogenic capsule and turn various knobs, and who pretend that the capsule is a submarine.  The test pilot wakes up, soon realizes that he'd been asleep for some 53 years, and sets forth with the goal of finding a co-worker who knew him from the 1930s.  Eventually, he finds the daughter of one of his co-workers (though the co-worker is deceased).  The daughter (now a middle-aged woman) rummages through her father's old belongings, and discovers a stack of laboratory notebooks on the cryogenic project, and gives them to the test pilot.  The test pilot then donates them to the U.S. Air Force, in view of the following fact.  The U.S. Air Force had continued its interest in cryogenics, but had never been able to reproduce the success of its own work from the 1930s.  The old laboratory notebooks are welcomed by the U.S. Air Force researchers, because they are perceived as providing enabling disclosures on how to do cryogenics.  A second theme occurs concurrently.  The second theme is that the test pilot had a fiance but shortly before he was to ask her to marry him, she is knocked unconscious in a traffic accident, and goes into a prolonged coma.  The location is identified, because we learn that the woman is being sent to a chronic care facility in Santa Rosa, which is in Northern California.  Because of Mel Gibson's grief  for his fiance, and because of all indications that she was destined to die, Mel Gibson volunteers for the cryogenic experiment.  After the test pilot wakes up some 53 years later, his interest in his fiance is revived, and he attempts to find her [DON'T WORRY, I DO NOT GIVE AWAY THIS PART OF THE STORY].The characters include the following:*  Mel Gibson (air force test pilot who volunteers for a cryogenic experiment, and is frozen in 1939)*  Jamie Lee Curtis (single mother of Elijah Wood, who provides food and shelter to Mel Gibson when he wakes up in 1992)*  Elijah Wood (ten year old son of Jamie Lee Curtis, and best friend of Robert Gorman)*  Robert Gorman (chubby friend of Elijah Wood)*  Isabel Glasser (Mel Gibson's fiance from the year 1939, who Mel Gibson searches for in the year 1992)1-LINERS AND QUIRKY DETAILS.  The film provides a number of clever 1-liners.  The screenplay was written by Jeffrey Abrams.  I am not sure how Mr. Abrams was able to think of all of the following situations and 1-liners.  Perhaps, Mr. Abrams is a genius.At the airfield, after Gibson concludes his flight with a crash-landing, he climbs out of the cockpit and quips, "If she comes with a warranty, I'll take her."  Right after that, Gibson talks to a reporter regarding the name of Gibson's character (McCormick).  Gibson quips, "McCormick, that's three C's, you figure it out."At a picnic, a boy holding an ice cream cone stares expressionlessly at Gibson.  Gibson reacts with humor, and holds blue teacups to his eyes and sticks out his tongue.  The boy continues to stare.  This little episode serves to convince the viewer that the story is a real one, in view of the fact that real-life sometimes comes with strange episodes that make no sense (and in view of the fact that screenplays usually only include episodes that further the plot line).In a railroad car diner, we see Gibson asking his girlfriend to get married.  Then, the camera pulls away, revealing that Gibson is only practicing his marriage proposal to an empty seat.When the two boys are in the air force warehouse, opening up the cryogenic device that contains Gibson, Gibson suddenly grabs and snatches the coat of one of the boys.  This was a matter of impulse, since Gibson was not awake and conscious at the time.  The boys run off, and seek the safety of a young soldier who had driven them to the air base, but who'd told them to stay in the car.  They tell the young soldier what had happened.  The soldier replies, "If I was cold, I'd probably take your jacket too."  (This is a very clever line.  The impact of the soldier's comment is that it displays ignorance, and that it is nonetheless true.  In other words, the ignorant comment is serendipitously true.)Also interesting, is the film's disclosure of the clumsiness of young teenagers and boys in their courting behavior.  This concerns the courting behavior of Elijah Wood, playing a ten year old.  To a girl he says, "I like your nail polish.  It looks like blood."  Then, also intending to impress her, he describes and displays a big scab on his knee.  "I thrashed my bike.  I got this big scab.  But I'm not going to pick it."  "Cool," replies the girl.GENERAL COMMENTS.  This is the best Disney movie that was never made by Disney.  Disney has made some great classics, for example, SHAGGY DOG (1959), ABSENT MINDED PROFESSOR (1961), SNOW WHITE (1938), and DUMBO (1941).  Disney has also made a large number of forgettable stinkers.  Now, in the best of the Disney movies, there are some goals that Disney strives for and succeeds in achieving.  These same goals are achieved with great magnificence in FOREVER YOUNG.  FOREVER YOUNG succeeds wonderfully on a variety of levels.  First of all, the movie shows an idealized and perfect play relationship of two boys with each other (Elijah Wood and Robert Gorman). This particular subject is the subject of many of the Disney movies. Second, the movie discloses a deep yearning for a lost love, in its depiction of Mel Gibson's eternal love for Isabel Glasser, and his quest for her even after the passage of 53 years.  Third, the movie succeeds admirably as a science fiction movie, for example, in its depiction of the cryogenic hardware, and in its convincing depiction of disbelieve by the military, when Mel Gibson voluntarily goes to a military base in the year 1992, and presents his case.  Fourth, another thing that I liked is the fact that parts of the movie take place in northern California.  I recognized the mouth of the Russian River, one of my all-time-great weekend vacation spots.  Also, I recognized the Point  Arena Lighthouse, which is shown I early in the movie during a flashback, and also in the  final moments of the movie, during Mel Gibson's quest for finding Isabel Glasser.  And fifth, I liked the classic automobiles and WWII airplanes, and an old-fashioned converted railroad car diner, all dating from the 1930s.COMPARISON WITH OTHER MOVIES AND BOOKS.  FOREVER YOUNG cannot be considered to be extremely original.  On the other hand, where a film or novel makes use of well-worn themes, but where the presentation of those themes succeeds much better than in previous films or novels, then the film is worthy of being considered to be a work of art.  In my opinion, FOREVER YOUNG is a work of art.  Not a scene in this movie is misplaced, forced, arbitrary, or dull.  Now, regarding the previously used elements, the following elements in FOREVER YOUNG may be found in the following films and books.FRANKENSTEIN (1931) directed by James Whale.  The scene where Mel Gibson wakes up from the frozen state, with a zombie-face, and automatically grabs the coat of one of the boys, is reminiscent of the scene from Frankenstein when the monster wakes up from the slabTIME MACHINE (2013) with Guy Pearce.  The relevant element is an aching, yearning love for a fiance taken away in an accident.HURRICANE (2008), a children's book by David Wiesner.  The relevant element is a boy in a treehouse pretending that he is in a sailing ship or in an airplane, where the treehouse actually turns into a ship or airplane.A RAGE TO LIVE (1964) with Bradford Dillman.  A man rescues a woman from a bully, where the man engages in a fistfight with the bully, and where the man is rewarded by kindness from the woman.WAR OF THE WORLDS (1995) with Tom Cruise.  The relevant element is excellent parental rapport of a man with a child.  Mel Gibson shows excellent rapport with Elijah Wood, when he teaches him to fly the pretend airplane in a treehouse, and when he coaches him in landing a real airplane at Point Arena, north of Salt Point State Park in Northern California.
summary: The best Disney movie that was never made by Disney

reviewText: In 1939, after losing his love, a test pilot volunteers for a cryogenics experiment and is "thawed out" 50 years later. This movie is a romantic drama, with a twist in the tale that changes everything. A truly amazing movie. Elijah Wood and Mel Gibson give a great performance that really do complement each other. A very touching movie for all to see.

reviewText: I ordered "Forever Young" DVD in Amazon.co.Uk and it cost me E2.54.  This DVD was never available in widescreen format on Region 1.  Most popular movies in Region 1 offered only in full screen format are available in Widescreen format in Region 2 via amazon.co.Uk and its costs less.Some of the Region 2 Widescreen DVD's I recently ordered from Amazon.co.UK:  Eve of Destruction E2.75; Toy Soldiers E2.47; Delta Force E3.34; Go Tell The Spartans E5.50 and more.  The quality of Region 2 are as good as Region 1 DVDs if not better.

reviewText: I liked this film enough to buy it on a widescreen laserdisc (remember those?). Why-oh-why does Warner Brothers DVD division insist on continuing to crank out good movies like this in full-screen format? It actually takes MORE effort to transfer a film in pan-and-scan than it does to simply transfer it in it's orignal aspect ratio. I am waiting to buy this film on DVD if it ever comes out in widescreen, but until then I am boycotting all WB full-screen DVD's regardless of how good the movie is. That is the only way they will wake up and get the message: WE WANT WIDESCREEN OR BOTH VERSIONS ON ONE DVD; NOT FULL-SCREEN ONLY!
summary: Wonderful film, but yet another WB full-screen transfer...
